intro: Elaeoselinum thapsoides, commonly known as the field eryngo, is a flowering plant native to Europe, North Africa, and parts of Asia. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender, hairy stems and alternate leaves that are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in clusters, which bloom from late spring to early summer. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in meadows, roadsides, and waste areas. Elaeoselinum thapsoides is known for its aromatic properties and has been used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
